content:
We are thinking of re-designing our /plans page to use a tab switcher, as it will be helpful when we add more plans on the page.

Current design: Screenshot-2022-01-05-at-9.43.17-AM.png
Any ideas on how to make it more evident which tab is selected?
color icon
with just 2 tabs is an old problem, the solution is to make both tabs look the same and add accent to another one
alternative is to make active button bigger
Good ideas.
so the most minimal action is to add a 2px-4px green border border to the grey button, so the will be kind of a group but at the same time one would be bigger
like this image.png
but still it is not 100% and hardly can be with 2 tabs
It is much more clear now though.
well.. its not really because background is preventing green button from standing out
so I would remove the background
this will also help to fix fuzzy contrast of grey boxes at the bottom
but probably thats a bigger change than just adding borders

I’m still not convinced that clarifies which one is selected. It would help if the middle border were rounded one way or the other.

  ___________________________
 /                /          \
|  not selected  |  selected  |
 \________________\__________/
Okay, let me try.
Screenshot-2022-01-05-at-10.13.41-AM.png
Screenshot-2022-01-05-at-10.16.15-AM.png
I didn’t intend to imply that it needed to be so bulbous—a tasteful slight rounding like our other rounded rectangles should suffice.

Guys I'm telling there is no easy exit from 2 tabs problem :)
image.png
now you can also say that active one is a white one not a green one
because white one is more contrasty from the background

also there could be old school people who would tell you that hey, green is active one because its kind of not clickable, and that is why its dimmed, while white one is clickable and that is why it's having a higher contrast.
I don’t know whether green=active or white=active is better, but the rounding makes it clear that green=active in Aman’s screenshots and white=active in Vlad’s screenshot.
@Aman Agrawal (amanagr) approach with roundy buttons works better without any borders, because it looks like a switch. Now if we add white borders, it will be even better. image.png
@Anders Kaseorg agree that rounding helps and also would suggest having borders around the whole button group to increase that effect.
Screen-Shot-2022-01-05-at-12.44.18-AM.png
In Mac's setting example they do use rounding and border. Active one is also the most contrasty to the background.
Should we play with different button colors to make it more clear which one is supposed to be higher contrast vs. the background?
The button in Anders Kaseorg 's screenshot, above, looks like it is slightly raised, which makes it prominent. Adding shadows might be worth experimenting with.
The button in Vlad Korobov 's latest screenshot, just above Anders Kaseorg 's, looks stylish.

left selected
right selected
Screenshot-2022-01-05-at-2.31.13-PM.png
Screenshot-2022-01-05-at-2.31.51-PM.png
We should just opt for the last screenshot as a simple change for now. Changing background color is too much of a change. We will have to adjust colors of a lot of subsequent buttons / links below.
Also, we should make the Register button color more darker.
guys I'm sorry but this is not looking good image.png
I don't see what the green border over the white border adds
In this case I would think that image.png white button is active. But I'm sure there would be people who think otherwise :)
I probably need to see this in action, but I kinda agree that the tabs here feel strange.

This is another idea that Atlassian uses
image.png

I don't know how to desing it well.
It seems like there should be a much more clear division between the two offerings (Cloud vs. Self-Host).

I would align things more like this:

image.png
Tabs definitely work better in terms of what is clear in case of 2 variants. And it's probably a bigger effort...

I don’t know if you were just trying different color conventions there, but just because the rounding makes it clear which convention is in use, doesn’t mean we should switch conventions when the user selects the other tab. We should still be consistent about which color represents the active tab.
It seems like the above screenshots use a grey background for the active tab. Would it look weird to have it be white?
I meant Aman’s earlier screenshots (“left selected”, “right selected”, etc.).
The “another idea that Atlassian uses” screenshot doesn’t work because the illusion of a tab is destroyed by the gradient shining through it.
I don't think there's anything wrong with a solution that includes removing the gradient -- we probably want to move away from that gradient anyway.
I'm not sure I'd go with a solid green background instead -- we could try just having a white/grey background and making the individual plan regions have a border or something.

Steve Howell (showell) said:

I would align things more like this:

image.png

Having 4 things side-by-side can have problems with responsive design for screens that aren't incredibly wide, which is why we were looking at a tabs-based solution. One can just stack things vertically with each other in less wide screens (E.g. have Cloud above Self Hosted), but it creates annoying constraints around details like how wide each of the 4 plan descriptions are.

I was responding to a screenshot with 4 things side by side, and I was assuming that was still our plan. If we continue with the 4 things side by side, then I think we should just divide the two things clearly.

I don't have any objections to tabs, especially if Zulip Cloud is open by default (or even better if the selected-tab takes into account the page you navigated from, if from within Zulip).
